summary: The Fair Play for Cuba Committee (FPCC) was an organization with pro-Castro sentiments. The documents suggest the FPCC was of interest to the FBI and CIA. Richard Thomas Gibson, also known as "Sugar," had connections with the FPCC and communist activities. The CIA proposed planting an article attacking the FPCC in a leading U.S. publication, using material partly provided by the FBI. Lee Harvey Oswald had contact with Richard Gibson and the FPCC. Michael Stratton had contact with Court Wood, a student with pro-Castro sentiments recently returned from Cuba under the sponsorship of the FPCC.
significance: The FPCC is significant in the JFK assassination context due to Lee Harvey Oswald's association with the organization and its potential connections to communist activities. The interest of the FBI and CIA in the FPCC suggests it was considered a relevant entity in the broader investigation.
